description:
'''Mary Elizabeth''' "'''Sissy'''" '''Spacek''' ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|s|p|eɪ|s|ɛ|k}}; born December 25, 1949) is an American actress and singer. She has received [[List of awards and nominations received by Sissy Spacek|numerous accolades]] throughout her career spanning over five decades, including an [[Academy Awards|Academy Award]], three [[Golden Globe Awards]], and a [[Screen Actors Guild Awards|Screen Actors Guild Award]] as well as nominations for four [[British Academy Film Awards]], three [[Primetime Emmy Awards]], and a [[Grammy Awards|Grammy Award]]. For her contributions to the [[film industry]], Spacek was honored with a star on the [[Hollywood Walk of Fame]] in 2011.

After attending the [[Lee Strasberg Theatre and Film Institute]], Spacek made her [[feature film]] debut in [[Michael Ritchie (filmmaker)|Michael Ritchie]]'s ''[[Prime Cut]]'' (1972). Her performance in [[Terrence Malick]]'s [[neo-noir]] crime drama film ''[[Badlands (film)|Badlands]]'' (1973), earned her a nomination for the [[BAFTA Award for Most Promising Newcomer to Leading Film Roles|BAFTA Award for Most Promising Newcomer]]. Spacek's [[Breakthrough role|breakthrough]] came when she played the abused teen misfit [[Carrie White|title character]] with [[Telekinesis|telekinetic]] powers in [[Brian De Palma]]'s supernatural horror film ''[[Carrie (1976 film)|Carrie]]'' (1976), which earned her first of six nominations for the [[Academy Award for Best Actress]]. She then starred in [[Robert Altman]]'s psychological drama film ''[[3 Women]]'' (1977). Spacek's complex performance as [[country music]] star [[Loretta Lynn]] in [[Michael Apted]]'s [[Biographical film|biographical]] musical film ''[[Coal Miner's Daughter (film)|Coal Miner's Daughter]]'' (1980), in which she portrayed Lynn from the age of about 13 to near middle age and did her own singing, earned her an Academy Award as well as a [[Golden Globe Award for Best Actress in a Motion Picture – Musical or Comedy|Golden Globe Award]]. She received four more Academy Award nominations for her roles in ''[[Missing (1982 film)|Missing]]'' (1982), ''[[The River (1984 film)|The River]]'' (1984), ''[[Crimes of the Heart (film)|Crimes of the Heart]]'' (1986), and ''[[In the Bedroom]]'' (2001). Spacek won a [[Golden Globe Award for Best Actress in a Motion Picture – Drama|Golden Globe Award]] for the latter. Her other notable films include ''[[Raggedy Man]]'' (1981), ''[[%27night,_Mother_(film)|'night, Mother]]'' (1986), ''[[The Long Walk Home]]'' (1990), ''[[JFK (film)|JFK]]'' (1991), ''[[Affliction (1997 film)|Affliction]]'' (1997), ''[[The Straight Story]]'' (1999), ''[[Nine Lives (2005 film)|Nine Lives]]'' (2005), ''[[North Country (film)|North Country]]'' (2005), ''[[Get Low (film)|Get Low]]'' (2010), ''[[The Help (film)|The Help]]'' (2011), ''[[The Old Man & the Gun]]'' (2018), and ''[[Sam & Kate]]'' (2022).

In television, Spacek received her first Primetime Emmy Award nomination for her role in the [[Western film|Western]] film ''[[The Good Old Boys (film)|The Good Old Boys]]'' (1995). She was later Emmy-nominated for [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Supporting Actress in a Limited or Anthology Series or Movie|Outstanding Supporting Actress in a Limited or Anthology Series or Movie]] and [[Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Guest Actress in a Drama Series|Outstanding Guest Actress in a Drama Series]] for her work in the drama film ''[[Last Call (2002 film)|Last Call]]'' (2002) and the [[HBO]] series ''[[Big Love]]'' (2010–2011), respectively. Spacek played matriarch Sally Rayburn in the [[Netflix]] series ''[[Bloodline (TV series)|Bloodline]]'' (2015–2017), Ruth Deaver in the [[Hulu]] series ''[[Castle Rock (TV series)|Castle Rock]]'' (2018), and Ellen Bergman in the [[Amazon Prime Video]] series ''[[Homecoming (TV series)|Homecoming]]'' (2018). Her other notable television work include the films ''[[The Migrants]]'' (1974), ''[[A Place for Annie]]'' (1994), ''[[If These Walls Could Talk]]'' (1996), ''[[Midwives (2001 film)|Midwives]]'' (2001) and ''[[Pictures of Hollis Woods (film)|Pictures of Hollis Woods]]'' (2007), and the series ''[[Night Sky (TV series)|Night Sky]]'' (2022).

Spacek has also ventured into the [[music industry]]. In 1968, under the [[stage name]] Rainbo, she recorded her debut [[Single (music)|single]] "John You Went Too Far This Time". When sales sputtered, Spacek was dropped by her [[record label]]. She later recorded vocals for the [[Coal Miner's Daughter (film)#Soundtrack|soundtrack album]] to ''Coal Miner's Daughter'', which peaked at No. 2 on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Top Country Albums]] chart and garnered her a nomination for the [[Grammy Award for Best Female Country Vocal Performance]]. Spacek subsequently released her debut [[Album#Types of album|studio album]], ''[[Hangin' Up My Heart]]'' (1983).
